text: n) causes a distinct ""fish-scale"" pattern.  Unlike other types of osteogenesis imperfecta, the whites of the eyes (sclerae) and teeth do not appear to be affected. The Human Phenotype Ontology provides the following list of signs and symptoms for Osteogenesis imperfecta type VI. If the information is available, the table below includes how often the symptom is seen in people with this condition.
